Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Synoptic Climatological Approaches to Assessing Subcanopy Hydrologic and Nutrient Fluxes in a Temperate Deciduous Forest

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This doctoral dissertation research project will focus on the flow of water and chemicals through forest canopies under different precipitation regimes. Deciduous temperate forests comprise over 280 million hectares in North and Central America and provide vital ecosystem services through the cycling of water and nutrients. During storm events, water moves through the forest canopy and exchanges nutrients and pollutants with vegetation and deposits the chemically altered precipitation to the forest floor. Both storm characteristics, such as intensity, duration, and magnitude, and the structural parameters of forest canopies have a significant control on the quantity and quality of such water, but how these may be influenced by altered precipitation regimes as a result of changing climates is largely uncertain. This project will yield a better understanding of the cycling of nutrients and pollutants within a forest canopy through hydrologic pathways that are ultimately controlled by atmospheric circulation and precipitation patterns at a field site in the Mid-Atlantic region. The doctoral student will link synoptic climatology with water and solute flux in temperate forests. Meteorological characteristics will be monitored at 5-minute intervals. These real-time ground observations will complement a long-term synoptic calendar, which will be developed to categorize common weather patterns experienced in the region. The partitioning of precipitation into throughfall (water intercepted by the canopy that continues to fall to the forest floor) and stemflow (water that is intercepted by the canopy and funneled down the tree trunk and deposited directly to the base of the tree) will be measured by automated tipping buckets at 5-minute intervals during storm events for two tree species of varying bark thickness and canopy geometry in order to understand the varying responses of precipitation in a heterogeneous forest canopy. Precipitation, throughfall, and stemflow samples will be collected after storm events and analyzed for important nutrients, such as dissolved organic carbon, calcium, magnesium, potassium, and sodium, and for anions, such as nitrates and sulfates, which can form acid rain.

This project will provide new methodologies for estimating hydrologic and nutrient fluxes in forest canopies by integrating techniques of synoptic climatology and weather pattern analysis. This study will demonstrate how synoptic analysis of large-scale atmospheric circulation patterns may be used to estimate surface environmental conditions, thus reducing the demand for costly, fine-scale field observations. The dataset compiled in this study will be used to reconstruct a historical nutrient budget of Mid-Atlantic forests of similar composition and potentially forecast changes in forest hydrologic and nutrient budgets as a result of climate-induced changes to precipitation regimes. A more thorough understanding of the movement of water, nutrients, and pollutants in forest ecosystems will improve management capabilities and climate change mitigation efforts. As a Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement award, this award also will provide support to enable a promising student to establish a strong independent research career.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Deciduous forests represent a significant land cover classification in much of the temperate United States and contribute meaningful ecosystem services such as carbon sequestration, water and air purification, storm water management, recreational retreats, in addition to providing valuable timber products. These services are constrained by both climate and forest health, which can be assessed through growth, water use and yield, resiliency to disturbance, and nutrient cycling. As water moves through the forest canopy during rainfall events, nutrients are cycled from the trees and the atmosphere to the forest floor.  The research funded by this project aimed to understand how forest nutrient cycling responds to external climate variables in conjunction with species-specific traits and seasonality (Figure). A new framework was developed to understand these complex relationships using weather map classification as a means to categorize the role of storm systems and the canopy-atmosphere interface in nutrient cycling.

This new framework provided the means to use map classification to understand water and nutrient cycling in forests. This approach simplified the complex relationships for easier analysis and provided results that will aid decision-making for researchers and forest managers. The utility of predicting forest nutrient status and health from weather map classification will benefit numerous stakeholders who benefit from forest services. Quantifying water and nutrient fluxes in relation to current and historical climatic settings furthers understanding of forest system functions and supplements modeling efforts on the nature of potential changes in forest productivity. A more thorough understanding of the movement of water and nutrients within these ecosystems improves our management and modeling capabilities.

Results have been submitted for publication and are being prepared for submission in high-impact peer-reviewed journals. The research carried out under this grant provided the doctoral student with professional experience in project management, field-based and laboratory research methods, data management and synthesis, and student mentoring that enabled her to land a tenure-track faculty position with the completion of her doctoral degree.
